# List of largest sports contracts

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The following is a **list of the largest sports contracts**. These figures
include [signing bonuses](/wiki/Signing_bonus "Signing bonus") but exclude
options, buyouts, and endorsement deals. This list does not reflect the
highest annual salaries or career earnings, only the largest contracts and
thus is limited to athletes in [team sports](/wiki/Team_sports "Team sports")
and [auto racing](/wiki/Auto_racing "Auto racing"). Athletes in [individual
sports](/wiki/Individual_sport "Individual sport"), such as [golf](/wiki/Golf
"Golf"), [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis"), and [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing")
are not employed by a team and usually earn money primarily through event
winnings. This list also does not necessarily reflect actual money collected
by the athletes, since some contracts are eventually terminated (usually due
to an athlete either retiring or invoking their opt-out clause).

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_largest_sports_contracts&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Notes")]

  * Contracts in the NFL are often not guaranteed, meaning that players who retire, or who are cut, do not receive their contracted salaries after their release from the team.
  * [NBA](/wiki/NBA "NBA") and [NHL](/wiki/NHL "NHL") seasons span two calendar years.
  * [Michael Vick](/wiki/Michael_Vick "Michael Vick") was suspended by the [NFL](/wiki/NFL "NFL") in 2007. The [Atlanta Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta Falcons") were unsuccessful in a civil legal process to attempt to recoup $20 million of the $100 million in bonuses paid to Vick under terms of his contract extension.
  * During his contract years, [Michael Schumacher](/wiki/Michael_Schumacher "Michael Schumacher") had significantly higher annual earnings than the athletes on this list with larger total contracts. On top of his $31 million per year paid by the [Ferrari](/wiki/Ferrari "Ferrari") team, which alone ranked as the highest annual earnings at the time, he also earned a significant amount more per year from race winnings.
  * [David Beckham](/wiki/David_Beckham "David Beckham") signed a five-year deal with [MLS](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer") [soccer](/wiki/Soccer "Soccer") team [Los Angeles Galaxy](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Galaxy "Los Angeles Galaxy") that was worth a reported $251 million,[130] but that figure included commercial endorsements; only $5 million a year of that figure is salary from the club, while the rest will come via existing endorsements and profit sharing with the club.[131][132]
  * [Lewis Hamilton](/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton "Lewis Hamilton") signed a contract with [McLaren Mercedes](/wiki/McLaren_Mercedes "McLaren Mercedes") worth at least ₤70 million ($138 million [USD](/wiki/United_States_Dollar "United States Dollar")) over 5 seasons (2008–2012). However, no official contract details have been released by the team.[133]
  * In 2010, the NHL rejected a 17-year, $102 million contract between the [New Jersey Devils](/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils "New Jersey Devils") and [Ilya Kovalchuk](/wiki/Ilya_Kovalchuk "Ilya Kovalchuk"), saying that the contract was "a circumvention of the [collective bargaining agreement](/wiki/Collective_bargaining_agreement "Collective bargaining agreement")." The later years of the contract would have paid Kovalchuk only $550,000 per year, which lowered the average value per year of the contract. (The [NHL's salary cap](/wiki/NHL_Salary_Cap "NHL Salary Cap") is based on the average value per year.) [134]
  *
